bibl.title: Letter from William S. Thayer to Mabel H. Lazear, April 19, 1926

div1.p: Thayer makes reference to Carter's experiments and their influence on Lazear. Thayer inquires if Lazear discussed his theories with her.

div1.head: Letter from William S. Thayer to Mabel H. Lazear, April 19, 1926

opener.dateline:
W. S. THAYER, M.D.
1208 EUTAW PLACE
BALTIMORE, MD.
April 19, 1926.

div1.p:
It is a long time since I have seen or heard from
you. I am writing to ask you a small question which
is not going to lead to any controversy, and about which
my mind is quite clear.

I have always thought that it was your husband who
on reading Carter's experiments immediately recognized
the similarity between the probable role of the mosquito
in yellow fever and that in malaria.-- And that it was
this recognition by Lazear that impressed Reed and turn-
ed the Commission immediately toward the study of the
mosquito.

Last spring I had a delightful talk with dear old
Carter in which he told me explicitly that he had shown
Lazear his paper before Reed had seen it and that Lazear
had immediately recognized its significance. Do you mind
telling me if you remember what Lazear wrote you about
it? I am perfectly clear in my own mind but I should be
very much interested to hear what you had to say.
